metadata.case_name: Golam Hussain alias Gama v. State

facts.text: Petitioner Golam Hussain alias Gama, an aged ailing man around 74, has been under detention since 1973.
Previous criminal prosecution against petitioner ended in discharge on July 19, 1973, the same date as detention order.
Commissioner of Police, Calcutta, passed initial detention order dated July 19, 1973 under S. 3(1)(a)(ii) read with sub-section (2) of Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 (MISA).

Grounds of detention communicated same day: On 8-10-72 at about 22-25 hrs., petitioner along with associates armed with bombs, soda-water bottles created disturbance on Gouri Sankar Lane by hurling bombs to attack Jiban Paul and group, terrorising locality.

Grounds of detention: On 9-11-72 between 04-45 hrs., petitioner along with associates armed with brickbats, soda-water bottles, bombs, poles created disturbance on Gouri Sankar Lane and Abinash Kaviraj Street by hurling items to overawe Kalipuja organisers, damaging lights, in sequel to earlier beer bottles thrown at pandal.
Petitioner's name not mentioned in first information reports of the two criminal cases; apprehended on July 4, 1973 based on evidence gathered during investigation.
Petitioner produced before Magistrate on July 5, 1973; discharged on July 19, 1973 as no witness dared to depose against him in open court, on prayer of police.
Fact of detention communicated to State Government, reported to Central Government.
Case placed before Advisory Board on August 13, 1973; detenu's representation received, considered and negatived by State Government, then to Board.
Advisory Board advised continuance of detention on September 21, 1973.
State Government confirming order dated September 28, 1973, unlimited in duration, unspeaking on terminus; communicated to detenu by middle of October 1973.

legal_issues.text: Whether detention order is mala fide or invalid because passed immediately after discharge in criminal cases for want of evidence.
Whether nine-month interval between incidents (Oct/Nov 1972) and detention order (July 1973) snaps the live link required for preventive detention.
Whether detention order confirming detention without specifying period violates Section 12 of MISA.
Whether grounds of detention pertain to maintenance of public order or merely private disputes.

petitioner_arguments.text: Detention irrational and mala fide as petitioner's name not in FIRs, produced before Magistrate only July 5, 1973, discharged July 19, 1973 due to no witnesses deposing.
Nine-month delay between incidents and detention order breaks live link; relied on Lakshman Khatik v. State of West Bengal and Rameshwar Shah v. District Magistrate Burdwan.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Lakshman Khatik v. State of West Bengal; Rameshwar Shah v. District Magistrate Burdwan

petitioner_arguments.text: Confirming order dated September 28, 1973 merely confirms detention without specifying period, violative of S.12 MISA.
Acts aimed at particular persons (Jiban Paul group, Kalipuja organisers), not public generally; does not affect public order.

respondent_arguments.text: Petitioner could not be arrested until July 4, 1973; discharged due to witnesses afraid to depose; detention preventive, not punitive.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Preventive detention distinct from punitive; M.S. Khan v. C.C. Bose; Ashim Kumar v. State of West Bengal; Sahib Singh Dugal v. Union of India

respondent_arguments.text: No mechanical test for interval; depends on nature of acts, reason for delay (investigation revealed involvement); acts serious, witnesses scared.
S.12 does not require specifying period in order; maximum under S.13; Government can revoke earlier.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 12, 13 MISA; Suna Ullah v. State of J&K; Dattatraya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. State of Bombay

respondent_arguments.text: Acts created terror in locality, disturbed normal life; amount to public order disturbance considering impact.

court_reasoning.text: Detention not mala fide merely because post-discharge for want of evidence; preventive detention distinct from punitive; subjective satisfaction not requiring proof beyond doubt.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discharge due to witnesses afraid does not make grounds baseless.

court_reasoning.text: No mechanical interval test; live link exists given serious acts (bomb hurling), discovery during investigation, witnesses scared; Commissioner satisfied.
S.12(1) does not require specifying period; maximum under S.13; Government can review and revoke; follows precedents.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not always practicable to specify; subject to statutory maximum.

court_reasoning.text: Acts though aimed at individuals created terror, panic in locality, disturbed public order; consider total effect, not isolate act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Nature, circumstances, impact constitute public disorder.

holdings.text: Preventive detention valid even if grounds subject of criminal cases ending in discharge for want of evidence.
Live link not snapped by nine-month interval in circumstances of serious acts and investigation delay.
Confirming order need not specify duration; valid under S.12, subject to S.13 maximum.
Grounds pertain to public order given terrorising effect on locality.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lakshman Khatik v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Live link and proximity between acts and detention order.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rameshwar Shah v. District Magistrate Burdwan

precedents_cited.relevance: Detention valid post-discharge in criminal case.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ashim Kumar v. State of West Bengal
Sahib Singh Dugal v. Union of India
Suna Ullah v. State of J&K
precedents_cited.relevance: No need to specify period in confirming order under S.12 MISA.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dattatraya Moreshwar Pangarkar v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Detention order valid without specifying period.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. Krishnan v. State of Madras
Prabhu Dayal v. District Magistrate, Kamrup
precedents_cited.relevance: Strict observance of procedure in detention.
Distinction between public order and private acts.

statutes_cited.name: Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 (Act 26 of 1971)
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for detention order, confirmation, maximum duration.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Original jurisdiction for habeas corpus writ petition.

outcome.summary: The Court dismissed the habeas corpus petition, upholding the validity of the preventive detention order under MISA, rejecting all contentions on mala fides, delay, unspecified duration, and public order.

key_quotes.text: The former relates to the punitive branch of the criminal law and relates to the past commission, the latter to the preventive branch of social defence and protects the community from future injury.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes preventive detention from punitive prosecution.

key_quotes.text: It is true that there must be a live link between the grounds of criminal activity alleged by the detaining authority and the purpose of detention, namely, inhibition of prejudicial activity of the species specified in the statute.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We cannot isolate the act from its public setting or analyse its molecules as in a laboratory but take its total effect on the flow of orderly life.
key_quotes.speaker: court
